DT Article
TI A new genus and species of polypore fungus beetle in Upper Cretaceous
   Burmese amber (Coleoptera, Tetratomidae, Eustrophinae).
AU Cai, Chenyang (cycai@nigpas.ac.cn) 
   Hsiao, Yun
   Huang, Diying
SO Cretaceous Research
VL 60
PS 275-280
PD May 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 14
AB A new polypore fungus beetle is described and figured from an individual
   preserved in Upper Cretaceous (Cenomanian, ca. 99 Ma) amber from
   northern Myanmar. Cretosynstrophus archaicus gen. et sp. nov. is
   confidently placed in the extant subfamily Eustrophinae based on its
   elongate oval body and pronotum with two basal, sublinear impressions.
   It shares several characters belonging to two Recent tribes (Eustrophini
   and Holostrophini), but it cannot be attributed to either of them.
   Together with other tetratomid genera from the Cretaceous, the new
   discovery implies that the Recent small family Tetratomidae is much more
   diverse and more widespread than previously documented. In addition, a
   morphological similarity between Cretosynstrophus and extant Synstrophus
   suggests a similar fungi feeding habit for Cretosynstrophus,
   highlighting an ancient association between tetratomid beetles and fungi
   in the Mesozoic. [copyright] 2015 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
C1 Cai, Chenyang; Chinese Acad Sci, Nanjing Inst Geol & Palaeontol, 39 East
   Beijing Rd, Nanjing, Jiangsu, 210008, China, China.
EM cycai@nigpas.ac.cn
SC Zoology
SN 0195-6671
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Oriental region;
   Eurasia; Asia; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Cretosynstrophus [Cretaceous /  / New genus]. 
   Cretosynstrophus archaicus [Myanmar /  / new species; Described from
   amber] [Cretaceous /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Tenebrionoidea,
   Tetratomidae
OR Cretosynstrophus (Tetratomidae): [Gen nov, Of subfamily Eustrophinae,
   Type species Cretosynstrophus archaicus, p. 276, Cretaceous; Fossil]. 
   Cretosynstrophus archaicus (Tetratomidae): [Sp nov, Myanmar, Cretaceous,
   P. 276, Described from amber; Fossil].

DT Article
TI An unusual new lineage of sawflies (Hymenoptera) in Upper Cretaceous
   amber from northern Myanmar.
AU Engel, Michael S. (msengel@ku.edu) 
   Huang, Diying
   Alqarni, Abdulaziz S.
   Cai, Chenyang
SO Cretaceous Research
VL 60
PS 281-286
PD May 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 1
U2 8
AB A peculiar new lineage of sawflies ('Symphyta') is described and figured
   from a female beautifully preserved in Upper Cretaceous (Cenomanian)
   amber from northern Myanmar. Syspastoxyela rhaphidia Engel and Huang,
   gen. et sp. nov., shares many plesiomorphic features with the primitive
   Xyelidae, [dagger]Xyelotomidae, and [dagger]Xyelydidae such as enlarged
   and thickened first flagellomere succeeded by a series of thinner and
   shorter flagellomeres, absence of a transverse mesoscutal sulcus,
   multiple preapical spurs, and two protibial spurs among other traits.
   However, the new lineage has an apomorphically contracted forewing
   venation, lacks a subcostal vein, has a single marginal cell, and lacks
   crossvein 1r-rs, and thus it is segregated into a new family,
   Syspastoxyelidae Engel and Huang, fam. nov. The phylogenetic affinities
   of the new family are discussed and a position near Pamphilioidea or
   Pamphilioidea + Unicalcarida is advocated. [copyright] 2015 Elsevier
   Ltd. All rights reserved.
C1 Engel, Michael S.; Univ Kansas, Div Entomol, 1501 Crestline Dr,Suite
   140, Lawrence, KS, 66045, USA, USA.
EM msengel@ku.edu
RI Engel, Michael S/C-5461-2012; Alqarni, Abdulaziz S./D-5246-2015
OI Engel, Michael S/0000-0003-3067-077X; Alqarni, Abdulaziz
   S./0000-0003-1324-332X
SC Zoology
SN 0195-6671
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Oriental region;
   Eurasia; Asia; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Syspastoxyela [Cretaceous /  / New genus]. 
   Syspastoxyela rhaphidia [Myanmar /  / new species; Described from amber]
   [Cretaceous /  / ]. 
   Syspastoxyelidae [Cretaceous /  / New family]. 
TN Arthropods; Hymenopterans; Insects; Invertebrates

   family Syspastoxyelidae, Type species Syspastoxyela rhaphidia Engel &
   Huang 2016, p. 283, Cretaceous; Fossil]. 
   Syspastoxyela rhaphidia - Engel & Huang 2016 (Hymenoptera): [Sp nov,
   Myanmar, Cretaceous, P. 283, Described from amber; Fossil].

DT Article
TI On the morphology of antennular sensory and attachment organs in cypris
   larvae of the deep-sea vent/seep barnacles, Ashinkailepas and
   Neoverruca.
AU Yorisue, Takefumi
   Chan, Benny K.K. (chankk@gate.sinica.edu.tw) 
   Kado, Ryusuke
   Watanabe, Hiromi
   Inoue, Koji
   Kojima, Shigeaki
   Hoeg, Jens T.
SO Journal of Morphology
VL 277
IS 5
PS 594-602
PD May 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 11
AB Barnacle cypris larvae show high morphological variation in the organs
   used in search of and attaching to a substratum. This variation may
   represent adaptation to the habitat of the species. Here, we studied SEM
   level morphologies of cypris antennular sensory and attachment organs in
   a deep-sea vent endemic species (Neoverruca sp.) and a vent/seep
   inhabiting species (Ashinkailepas seepiophila). We compare them with
   three species from other environments. The antennular morphologies of
   Neoverruca sp. and A. seepiophila were similar, which is consistent with
   recent molecular studies showing a close relationship of the two
   species. The setation pattern of the antennules was very conservative
   among species from various environments. In contrast, striking
   differences were observed in the structure of the attachment organ (the
   third antennular segment). Neoverruca sp. and A. seepiophila had no
   velum or a skirt surrounding the attachment disc on the third segment,
   while other cirripede cyprids almost always have either of these
   structures. In addition, both cyprids of A. seepiophila and Neoverruca
   sp. had the attachment disc angled toward the substratum, whereas it
   faces distally in cyprids from hard bottom inhabiting barnacles. We
   suggest that both velum/skirt and the angle of the attachment disc play
   an important role, when the antennules are contacting the substratum
   during surface exploration. Differences in attachment organ structures
   may be highly adaptive, enabling cirripede species to enter new habitats
   during evolution. J. Morphol. 277:594-602, 2016. [copyright] 2016 Wiley
   Periodicals, Inc.
C1 Chan, Benny K.K.; Acad Sinica, Res Ctr Biodivers, Taipei, 115, Taiwan,
   Taiwan.
EM chankk@gate.sinica.edu.tw
OI Chan, Benny/0000-0001-9479-024X; Watanabe, Hiromi/0000-0001-5031-9018
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Evolutionary Biology; Marine &Freshwater
   Biology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 0362-2525
BD General morphology; Appendages; Sensory reception; Evolution; Habitat;
   Marine zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Ashinkailepas seepiophila; Neoverruca [Adhesive organs / Antennular
   sensory & attachment organs / comparative study] [Antennules /  / ]
   [Sensory reception /  / ] [Phylogeny /  / ] [Marine habitat / Deep sea
   habitat / ] [North Pacific / Japan, Honshu, Izu Islands, Myojin Knoll /
   ]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Cirripedia, Thoracica, Verrucomorpha

   Neoverruca (Verrucomorpha).

DT Article
TI Phylogeography of the Lacerta viridis complex: mitochondrial and nuclear
   markers provide taxonomic insights.
AU Marzahn, Ellen
   Mayer, Werner
   Joger, Ulrich
   Ilgaz, Cetin
   Jablonski, Daniel
   Kindler, Carolin
   Kumlutas, Yusuf
   Nistri, Annamaria
   Schneeweiss, Norbert
   Vamberger, Melita
   Zagar, Anamarija
   Fritz, Uwe (ellen.marzahn@senckenberg.de) 
SO Journal of Zoological Systematics and Evolutionary Research
VL 54
IS 2
PS 85-105
PD May 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 30
AB Based on broad, nearly rangewide sampling, we reanalysed the
   phylogeography of the Lacerta viridis complex using the mitochondrial
   cytochrome b gene and the intron 7 of the nuclear -fibrinogen gene.
   Using the mitochondrial marker, we identified in phylogenetic analyses
   10 terminal clades clustering in four deeply divergent main lineages
   whose relationships are weakly resolved. These lineages correspond to
   Lacertabilineata, L.viridis, the previously identified Adriatic or West
   Balkan lineage and a newly discovered fourth lineage from the Anatolian
   Black Sea coast and the south-eastern Balkan Peninsula. Except for the
   latter lineage, there is considerable phylogeographic structuring in
   each lineage, with higher diversity in the south of the distribution
   ranges. This pattern indicates the existence of two distinct
   microrefugia in the Italian Peninsula and Sicily and of up to seven
   microrefugia in the Balkan Peninsula, but of only one refugium along the
   Black Sea coast of Anatolia. We identified secondary contact zones of
   the main lineages and of terminal clades within these lineages. However,
   most of the formerly described putative contact zone of L.bilineata and
   L.viridis turned out to be a contact zone between the Adriatic lineage
   and L.viridis, but L.bilineata seems to be involved only marginally. Our
   nuclear marker could not unambiguously resolve whether there is gene
   flow in contact zones. Thus, further research is necessary to decide
   whether the four main lineages are conspecific or whether they represent
   distinct biological species. We restrict the name L.v.meridionalis to
   the newly identified genetic lineage from Turkey and south-eastern
   Europe, synonymize some previously recognized taxa and suggest a
   tentative nomenclature for the L.viridis complex.
C1 Fritz, Uwe; Museum Zool, Senckenberg Dresden, Germany, Germany.
EM ellen.marzahn@senckenberg.de
RI Zagar, Anamarija/AAD-9386-2020; Jablonski, Daniel/I-7693-2019; Fritz,
   Uwe/AAC-4029-2019; Ilgaz, Cetin/P-6603-2019; Jablonski,
   Daniel/AAT-7357-2020
OI Zagar, Anamarija/0000-0003-2165-417X; Jablonski,
   Daniel/0000-0002-5394-0114; Vamberger, Melita/0000-0002-1404-2469
SC Zoology; Biochemistry &Molecular Biology; Genetics &Heredity;
   Evolutionary Biology
SN 0947-5745
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Synonymy; Biochemistry; Genetics; Population
   genetics; Evolution; Zoogeography
DE Lacerta viridis complex [Nucleic acids / Mt & nuclear markers /
   taxonomic implications] [Molecular genetics /  / ] [Gene flow /  / ]
   [Phylogeny / Phylogeography / ] [Zoogeography /  / ]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Lepidosauria, Squamata,
   Sauria, Lacertidae
OR Lacerta bilineata bilineata - Daudin 1802 (Lacertidae): [Syn nov,
   Lacerta bilineata chlorosecunda Taddei 1950, p. 92; Syn nov, Lacerta
   bilineata fejervaryi Vasvary 1926, p. 92]. 
   Lacerta viridis complex (Lacertidae). 
   Lacerta viridis meridionalis - Cyren 1933 (Lacertidae): [Syn nov,
   Lacerta viridis infrapunctata Schmidtler 1986, p. 93; Syn nov, Lacerta
   viridis paphlagonica Schmidtler 1986, p. 93].

DT Article
TI Long-term survival and diversification of an endemic Melitaea species in
   mountains of Iran and adjacent areas.
AU Toth, Janos P. (acutiformis@yahoo.com) 
   Varga, Zoltan
   Bereczki, Judit
SO Journal of Zoological Systematics and Evolutionary Research
VL 54
IS 2
PS 106-115
PD May 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 10
AB Disjunct distribution patterns regularly resulted in the separation of
   different genetic lineages in glacial refugia. Recent patterns of
   survival and expansion have been often revealed by climatic niche
   modelling. We used the combination of genetic markers, geometric
   morphometry and climatic niche modelling to clear up the taxonomy and
   reconstruct the potential range of an endemic Iranian, taxonomically
   disputed Melitaea species in climatically different epochs. Our results
   show that this species (Melitaea abbas Gross and Ebert 1975, comb.
   n.=M.zagrosi Toth and Varga syn. nova) is clearly separated from all
   taxa of the Melitaea phoebe species group and only occurs in Iran and
   Azerbaijan but were also predicted for some adjacent regions. Molecular
   markers and distribution modelling show consistently that this species
   should have had a long-term survival in this area, and its range could
   have been slightly larger during the last glacial maximum than
   currently. Based on the studied molecular markers, three main groups in
   M.abbas can be recognized: those of steppic area of Azerbaijan, western
   Iran and northeastern Iran. Each group is characterized by own
   mitochondrial haplotypes, but also a high level of genetic diversity
   appears in the central part of the distribution area (Zagros Mts.).
C1 Toth, Janos P.; Univ Debrecen, MTA DE Lendulet Behav Ecol Res Grp,
   Debrecen, Hungary, Hungary.
EM acutiformis@yahoo.com

   [Biometrics / Geometric morphometrics / ] [Molecular genetics / DNA

   / Iran & adjacent areas / ].

   Melitaea zagrosi (Toth & Varga 2011), p. 110]. 
   Melitaea phoebe abbas - (Gross & Ebert 1975) (Nymphalidae): [Raised to,

DT Article
TI Microbial Genomics of a Host-Associated Commensal Bacterium in
   Fragmented Populations of Endangered Takahe.
AU Grange, Zoe L. (z.grange@massey.ac.nz) 
   Gartrell, Brett D.
   Biggs, Patrick J.
   Nelson, Nicola J.
   Anderson, Marti
   French, Nigel P.
SO Microbial Ecology
VL 71
IS 4
PS 1020-1029
PD May 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 3
U2 29
AB Isolation of wildlife into fragmented populations as a consequence of
   anthropogenic-mediated environmental change may alter host-pathogen
   relationships. Our understanding of some of the epidemiological features
   of infectious disease in vulnerable populations can be enhanced by the
   use of commensal bacteria as a proxy for invasive pathogens in natural
   ecosystems. The distinctive population structure of a well-described
   meta-population of a New Zealand endangered flightless bird, the takahe
   (Porphyrio hochstetteri), provided a unique opportunity to investigate
   the influence of host isolation on enteric microbial diversity. The
   genomic epidemiology of a prevalent rail-associated endemic commensal
   bacterium was explored using core genome and ribosomal multilocus
   sequence typing (rMLST) of 70 Campylobacter sp. nova 1 isolated from one
   third of the takahe population resident in multiple locations. While
   there was evidence of recombination between lineages, bacterial
   divergence appears to have occurred and multivariate analysis of 52
   rMLST genes revealed location-associated differentiation of C. sp. nova
   1 sequence types. Our results indicate that fragmentation and
   anthropogenic manipulation of populations can influence host-microbial
   relationships, with potential implications for niche adaptation and the
   evolution of micro-organisms in remote environments. This study provides
   a novel framework in which to explore the complex genomic epidemiology
   of micro-organisms in wildlife populations.
C1 Grange, Zoe L.; Massey Univ, Inst Vet Anim & Biomed Sci, Palmerston
   North, New Zealand, New Zealand.
EM z.grange@massey.ac.nz
RI French, Nigel/F-5725-2011; Biggs, Patrick Jon/H-3355-2014
OI French, Nigel/0000-0002-6334-0657; Biggs, Patrick
   Jon/0000-0002-0285-4101; Nelson, Nicola/0000-0002-1641-6030; Gartrell,
   Brett/0000-0002-8062-9313
SC Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 0095-3628

   Bacterial commensals].

DT Article
TI Genomic Analyses Reveal Demographic History and Temperate Adaptation of
   the Newly Discovered Honey Bee Subspecies Apis mellifera sinisxinyuan n.
   ssp.
AU Chen, Chao
   Liu, Zhiguang
   Pan, Qi
   Chen, Xiao
   Wang, Huihua
   Guo, Haikun
   Liu, Shidong
   Lu, Hongfeng
   Tian, Shilin
   Li, Ruiqiang
   Shi, Wei (shiweibri@126.com) 
SO Molecular Biology and Evolution
VL 33
IS 5
PS 1337-1348
PD May 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 2
U2 39
AB Studying the genetic signatures of climate-driven selection can produce
   insights into local adaptation and the potential impacts of climate
   change on populations. The honey bee (Apis mellifera) is an interesting
   species to study local adaptation because it originated in
   tropical/subtropical climatic regions and subsequently spread into
   temperate regions. However, little is known about the genetic basis of
   its adaptation to temperate climates. Here, we resequenced the whole
   genomes of ten individual bees from a newly discovered population in
   temperate China and downloaded resequenced data from 35 individuals from
   other populations. We found that the new population is an undescribed
   subspecies in the M-lineage of A. mellifera (Apis mellifera
   sinisxinyuan). Analyses of population history show that long-term global
   temperature has strongly influenced the demographic history of A. m.
   sinisxinyuan and its divergence from other subspecies. Further analyses
   comparing temperate and tropical populations identified several
   candidate genes related to fat body and the Hippo signaling pathway that
   are potentially involved in adaptation to temperate climates. Our
   results provide insights into the demographic history of the newly
   discovered A. m. sinisxinyuan, as well as the genetic basis of
   adaptation of A. mellifera to temperate climates at the genomic level.
   These findings will facilitate the selective breeding of A. mellifera to
   improve the survival of overwintering colonies.
C1 Shi, Wei; Minist Agr, Key Lab Pollinating Insect Biol, Beijing, China,
   China.
EM shiweibri@126.com
RI Tian, Shilin/AAP-9998-2020
OI Chen, Chao/0000-0002-9582-1105
SC Zoology
SN 0737-4038
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Apis mellifera sinisxinyuan [Xinjiang Uygur /  / New subspecies]. 
TN Arthropods; Hymenopterans; Insects; Invertebrates

   Apidae

   1338].

DT Article
TI Nematode associates and bacteria in ant-tree symbioses.
AU Maschwitz, Ulrich (maschwitz@bio.uni-frankfurt.de) 
   Fiala, Brigitte
   Dumpert, Klaus
   bin Hashim, Rosli
   Sudhaus, Walter
SO Symbiosis
VL 69
IS 1
PS 1-7
PD May 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 28
AB Ant-plant mutualisms are a prominent phenomenon in tropical rainforest
   ecosystems. In South East Asia the most important ant-tree symbiosis is
   the Macaranga complex. Until now it has been known to consist of four
   obligate and specific partner organisms, trees, ants, endophytic
   trophobiotic scale insects and endophytic fungi. Here we show that two
   more organisms are integrated in the system. In the stem domatia, masses
   of bacteria were cultivated in piles consisting of plant food body
   remains and ant faeces. They were consumed by masses of specific
   bacteriovorous nematodes. The nematodes could be identified as
   rhabditids, mainly Diploscapter sp., as well as a few Sclerorhabditis
   specimens belonging to two new species. These genera are known to be
   myrmecophilous and suspected of being consumed and digested by the ants.
   We hypothesize that with this new type of two-step association the ants
   obtain and recycle scarce nutrients. This is important in a system where
   the specific ants are highly adapted to the association, and depend
   exclusively on plant resources as they do not hunt and forage off the
   plant. The nematodes are even vertically transferred by the swarming
   queens and therefore present in new claustral colony foundations.
   Nematode breeding was found in three further, but not in all
   investigated tree-ant associations. These observations underline the
   still largely unexplored role of micro-symbionts in insects, and a
   potential new source of complexity in the trophic interactions in
   tropical ecosystems.
C1 Maschwitz, Ulrich; Univ Frankfurt, Fachbereich Biowissensch, Anemonenweg
   33, Neu Isenburg, D-63263, Germany, Germany.
EM maschwitz@bio.uni-frankfurt.de
RI Fiala, Brigitte/I-3788-2016; Hashim, Rosli/A-8555-2010
OI Fiala, Brigitte/0000-0002-9625-1933
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology
SN 0334-5114
BD Associations; Land zones; Oriental region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Crematogaster captiosa [Associations / Bacteria / Involvement in plant
   mutualism] [ / Nematoda / ] [Mutualism / Macaranga bancana (plant) /
   Nematode associates & bacteria involvement] [Malaysia / West / Plant
   mutualists]. 
   Nematoda [Associations / Crematogaster captiosa (Hymenoptera) /
   Involvement in plant mutualism] [Malaysia / West / Hymenopteran
   associates]. 
TN Arthropods; Hymenopterans; Insects; Invertebrates; Nematodes
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hymenoptera, Apocrita, Aculeata,
   Formicoidea, Formicidae

   Crematogaster captiosa (Formicidae). 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15206039429

PT J
AN ZOOR15206039512
PM 27095661
DT Article
TI Neopsilotrema n. g. (Digenea: Psilostomidae) and three new species from
   ducks (Anseriformes: Anatidae) in North America and Europe.
AU Kudlai, Olena
   Pulis, Eric E.
   Kostadinova, Aneta
   Tkach, Vasyl V. (vasyl.tkach@email.und.edu) 
SO Systematic Parasitology
VL 93
IS 4
PS 307-319
PD May 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 2
U2 13
AB Neopsilotrema n. g. (Digenea: Psilostomidae) and three new species of
   psilostomid digeneans are described from birds in North America and
   Europe: Neopsilotrema lakotae n. sp. from Aythya americana (Eyton) in
   North Dakota, USA, Neopsilotrema affine n. sp. from Aythya affinis
   (Eyton) in Minnesota, USA and Neopsilotrema lisitsynae n. sp. from Anas
   crecca L. in Kherson Region, Ukraine. Neopsilotrema n. g. shares a
   bipartite seminal vesicle with only three genera within the
   Psilostomidae, Psilotornus Byrd & Prestwood, 1969, Psilostomum Looss,
   1899 and Grysoma Byrd, Bogitsh & Maples, 1961. The new genus differs
   from Psilotornus in the presence of a muscular pharynx and a massive
   ventral sucker; the location of the cirrus-sac in relation to the
   ventral sucker and more posterior location of ovary; the nature of the
   vitellarium (i.e. comprising large, compact follicles with small
   vitelline cells vs weakly defined follicles with large vitelline cells);
   a proportionately shorter forebody; and in parasitisation in anseriform
   (vs passeriform) birds. Differences between the new genus and
   Psilostomum comprise the shape of the body, the relative size of the
   suckers, somewhat longer forebody and a more anterior location of the
   testes. Neopsilotrema n. g. differs from Grysoma in the relative size of
   the suckers, the degree of development of prostatic cells, the nature of
   the vitellarium and the size of the eggs in relation to body length. The
   European species Neopsilotrema lisitsynae n. sp. is distinguished from
   its congeners in having a longer, narrower and distinctly more elongate
   body with a longer post-testicular region and anterior limits of the
   vitelline fields posterior to ventral sucker. The two North American
   forms, Neopsilotrema lakotae n. sp. and Neopsilotrema affine n. sp., are
   cryptic species with largely overlapping metrical data; these are
   distinguished by comparing genetic data. The phylogenetic hypotheses for
   the Psilostomidae developed from sequence data analyses based on partial
   28S rDNA support the erection of the new genus and the distinction of
   the three new species. Grysoma marilae (Price, 1942) agrees more closely
   with the generic diagnosis of Neopsilotrema, especially in relation to
   the size and shape of the body, the relative length of the forebody and
   post-testicular field, the structure of the vitellarium, the location of
   the reproductive organs and the sucker ratio. Consequently, it is here
   transferred to the new genus as Neopsilotrema marilae (Price, 1942) n.
   comb.
C1 Tkach, Vasyl V.; Univ N Dakota, Dept Biol, 10 Cornell St, Grand Forks,
   ND, 58202, USA, USA.

DT Article
TI Revision of Metahaliotrema Yamaguti, 1953 (Monogenoidea:
   Dactylogyridae), with new and previously described species from the
   spotted scat Scatophagus argus (Linnaeus) (Perciformes: Scatophagidae)
   in Vietnam.
AU Kritsky, Delane C. (kritdela@isu.edu) 
   Ha Van Nguyen
   Ngo Duy Ha
   Heckmann, Richard A.
SO Systematic Parasitology
VL 93
IS 4
PS 321-335
PD May 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 11
AB An emended diagnosis of Metahaliotrema Yamaguti, 1953 (Monogenoidea:
   Dactylogyridae) is provided based on specimens of six species collected
   from the spotted scat Scatophagus argus (Linnaeus) (Scatophagidae) in
   Vietnam: M. scatophagi Yamaguti, 1953 (type-species); M. cf. yamagutii
   Mizelle & Price, 1964; M. mizellei Venkatanarasaiah, 1981; M. kulkarnii
   Venkatanarasaiah, 1981; M. ypsilocleithrum n. sp.; and M. similis n. sp.
   Methaliotrema filamentosum Venkatanarasaiah, 1981 from the whipfin
   silver-biddy Gerres filamentosus Cuvier (Gerreidae) is included as the
   only other valid member of the genus. Metahaliotrema arii Yamaguti, 1953
   from an ariid catfish is considered incertae sedis within the
   Dactylogyridae; and Metahaliotrema srivastavai Singh & Agarwal, 1994
   from a bagrid catfish is transferred to Chauhanellus Bychowsky &
   Nagibina, 1969 as Chauhanellus srivastavai (Singh & Agarwal, 1994) n.
   comb. Metahaliotrema geminatohamula Pan, Ding & Zhang, 1995 from spotted
   scat in China is determined to be a junior subjective synonym of M.
   scatophagi. The two new species and M. scatophagi, M. mizellei, and M.
   kulkarnii are described or redescribed based on specimens from Vietnam.

DT Article
TI A new species of Dendromonocotyle Hargis, 1955 (Monogenea:
   Monocotylidae) from the skin of Zearaja chilensis (Guichenot)
   (Rajiformes: Rajidae) from the Argentine Sea.
AU Irigoitia, Manuel M. (manuelirigoitia@gmail.com) 
   Chisholm, Leslie A.
   Timi, Juan T.
SO Systematic Parasitology
VL 93
IS 4
PS 367-374
PD May 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 1
U2 4
AB Dendromonocotyle rajidicola n. sp. is described from the dorsal surface
   of the yellownose skate Zearaja chilensis (Guichenot) (Rajiformes)
   caught on the Argentine shelf. Dendromonocotyle rajidicola n. sp. can be
   distinguished from the other 17 species in the genus by the morphology
   of the distal portion of the male copulatory organ and by the unique
   morphology of the sclerotised proximal portion of the vagina. This is
   the first species of Dendromonocotyle to be described from a host in the
   Rajiformes and also the first record of this genus in the southwestern
   Atlantic Ocean.

DT Article
TI Two new axinid species (Monogenea: Axinidae) from the Pharao flyingfish
   Cypselurus naresii (Gunther) (Beloniformes: Exocoetidae) in the Gulf of
   Tonkin off Vietnam.
AU Hung Manh Nguyen (hung_iebr@yahoo.com) 
   Ha Van Nguyen
   Thanh Ngoc Bui
   Ngo Duy Ha
SO Systematic Parasitology
VL 93
IS 4
PS 387-394
PD May 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB A total of 21 Pharao flyingfish Cypselurus naresii (Gunther) from the
   Gulf of Tonkin off Vietnam was examined for monogeneans. Ten individuals
   were parasitised by 72 specimens of two new axinid species of two rare
   and little known genera, Unnithanaxine Price, 1962 containing only one
   species, U. parawa (Unnithan, 1957), and Loxuroides Price, 1962
   containing two species, L. sasikala (Unnithan, 1957) and L.
   fungilliformis Zhang, Ding, Liu & Wang, 1999. Unnithanaxine naresii n.
   sp. and Loxuroides pricei n. sp. are described and differentiated from
   the related species. Unnithanaxine naresii n. sp. is morphologically
   similar to U. parawa but is distinguished by the size of the clamps and
   reproduction organs, the number of spines in the lateral groups of the
   genital atrium, and in parasitism in a host fish species of a different
   genus. Loxuroides pricei n. sp. differs from L. fungilliformis in the
   greater size of the body, the number of clamps, testes, spines on cirrus
   and genital atrium, and in parasitism in a different host family.
   Similarly, L. pricei can be separated from L. sasikala in having a
   shorter distance from the anterior extremity to genital atrium or
   vaginal region, fewer testes, and a slightly greater number of spines on
   cirrus and genital atrium.
C1 Hung Manh Nguyen; Vietnam Acad Sci & Technol, Insititute Ecol & Biol
   Resources, 18 Hoang Quoc Viet St, Hanoi, Vietnam, Vietnam.

DT Article
TI Rotylenchus sardashtensis n. sp., a monosexual species from Iran, with
   molecular identification and detailed morphological observations on an
   Iranian population of Rotylenchus cypriensis Antoniou, 1980 (Nematoda:
   Rhabditida: Hoplolaimidae).
AU Golhasan, Behrouz
   Heydari, Ramin (rheydari@ut.ac.ir) 
   Alvarez-Ortega, Sergio
   Meckes, Oliver
   Pedram, Majid
   Atighi, Mohammad Reza
SO Systematic Parasitology
VL 93
IS 4
PS 395-411
PD May 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 7
AB Rotylenchus sardashtensis n. sp., a new monosexual species is described
   and illustrated based on morphological, morphometric and molecular
   studies. Rotylenchus sardashtensis n. sp. appears close morphologically
   and molecularly to eight known species of the genus, i.e. R. buxophilus
   Golden, 1956, R. eximius Siddiqi, 1964, R. breviglans Sher, 1965, R.
   cypriensis Antoniou, 1980, R. pakistanensis Maqbool & Shahina, 1986, R.
   vitis Cantalapiedra-Navarrete, Li,banas, Archidona-Yuste, Palomares-Rius
   & Castillo, 2012, R. paravitis Cantalapiedra-Navarrete, Navas-Cort,s,
   Li,banas, Vovlas, Subbotin, Palomares-Rius & Castillo, 2013 and R.
   dalikhaniensis Aliramaji, Pourjam, Alvarez-Ortega, Pedram & Atighi, 2015
   from which the morphological differences are discussed. The new species
   is characterised mainly in having a hemispherical and well set off lip
   region with 3-4 annuli under light microscopy and irregular cob-like
   appearance under scanning electron microscopy (SEM), a stylet 26-30
   A[mu]m long, a vulva located at 61-77% of body length with double
   epiptygma, rounded tail with 2-4 annuli and ventral mucron at its tip.
   Morphologically, R. sardashtensis n. sp. could be distinguished from all
   similar species within the genus by its matrix code as follows: A3, B1,
   C1, D4, E1, F2, G2, H5, I2, J2, K1. Rotylenchus cypriensis collected
   from the rhizosphere of Prunus sp. in Gilangharb region is characterised
   with its morphological and molecular data. Phylogenetic analyses based
   on sequences of the D2-D3 expansion region of the 28S rRNA gene and the
   ITS1 fragment revealed the relationships of both species examined in
   present study and other species of the genus Rotylenchus Filipjev, 1936
   and the family Hoplolaimidae Filipjev, 1934 included in analyses.

DT Article
TI PECTAPALOCHRUS GEN. N., A NEW GENUS OF SOFT-WINGED FLOWER BEETLES OF THE
   TRIBE APALOCHRINI (COLEOPTERA, MALACHIIDAE).
AU Tshernyshev, S.E. (sch-sch@mail.ru) 
SO Zoologicheskii Zhurnal
VL 95
IS 3
PS 300-306
PD May 2016
PY 2016
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 2
AB Analysis of species of Dromanthomorphus Pic from South-East Asia showed
   that the genus was distinguished by the following special male
   characters: flabellate, serrate, or filiform antennae, monochrome white
   pubescence of surface, swollen metathorax with gladiate appendage, stout
   and excavate anterior and intermediate tibiae, elongate and modified
   anterior and intermediate coxae, apical tergites with specific slanting
   and like tiles sculpture at tip, apical sternites bilaciniate, with
   specifically sculptured apices. These characters are completely lacking
   in Palaearctic species of Dromanthomorphus, which are characterized by
   flabellate or serrate antennae, simple, not swollen metathorax lacking
   appendages, double pubescence of surface, white and black in colour,
   apical tergites simple, evenly rounded, apical sternites evenly
   narrowed, emarginate in middle, with simple, not sculptured apices. On
   the basis of these different characters, a new genus, Pectapalochrus
   gen. n., is described for Palaearctic species. Keys to Pectapalochrus
   species and Apalochrini of Eurasia, as well as illustrations of overall
   morphology and male structures of the new genus are given.
C1 Tshernyshev, S.E.; Russian Acad Sci, Siberian Branch, Novosibirsk,
   630091, Russia, Russia.
EM sch-sch@mail.ru

DT Article
TI Two new species of Hypoaspis from Helan Mountain Nature Reserve of
   Ningxia, China (Acari: Laelapidae).
AU Bai Xue-Li (nxbaixl@sina.com) 
   Yan Yi
   Zhang Tao
SO Acta Arachnologica Sinica
VL 25
IS 1
PS 6-13
PD May 2016
PY 2016
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 0
AB This paper describes two new species Hypoaspis (Cosmolaelaps)
   helanshanensis sp. nov. and Hypoaspis (Cosmolaelaps) liujingyuani sp.
   nov., in the genus Hypoaspis Canestrini, 1885. All specimens were
   collected from Helan Mountain Nature Reserve of Ningxia Hui Autonomous
   Region, China, from nest of Myrmos spp.. The type specimens are
   deposited in the Collection of the Medical Entomology of Institute of
   Microbiology and Epidemiology Academy of Military Medical Science,
   Beijing, China and Ningxia Hui Autonomous Region Center for Disease
   Control and Prevention, Yinchuan, Ningxia, China. The genus Hypoaspis
   was erected by Canestrini in 1885, belongs to Laelapidae Berlese,
   Karg(1979) divided Hypoaspis into eight subgenera: Hypoaspis Canestrini,
   Hypohasta Karg, Cosmolaelaps Berlese, Alloparasitus Berlese, Geolaelaps
   Tragardh, Pneumolaelaps Berlese, Holostaspis Kolenati and Laelaspis
   Berlese; while Evans & Till(1979) promoted these subgenera(Cosmolaelaps,
   Holostaspis, Pneumolaelaps, and Laelaspis) to genera. This paper follws
   Kart(1979). Up to now, Hypoaspis has a total of more than 170 known
   species worldwide, and more than 60 species(subspecies) of them have
   been reported from China(Teng, 1993; Bai et al. 1993; 1994; 1995; 2002;
   2012; Bei et al. 2003; Gu a al. 1990; 1991; 1992; Liu, et al. 1996; Ma
   et al. 1996; 1997; 1998; 2000; 2003; 2004; 2009; 2010; Xu et al. 1996).
   Two new species of Hypoaspis were collected from Helan Mountain Nature
   Reserve of Ningxia Hui Autonomous Region, China, from nest of Myrmos
   spp. in this paper. Terminology used for the dorsal idiosomal chaetotaxy
   follows Kart (1979), the measurements are given in [mu]m. 1
   Hypoaspis(Cosmolaelaps) helanshanensis sp. nov.(Figs. 1-10) Female.
   Idoosoma faint yellow, shape oval, length 637(623-651), width
   435(429-440). Dorsal shield completed, covering all the dorsum almost,
   length 612(608-616), width 419(415-422); with 39 pairs of setae and
   three unpaired accessory setae between D5-D8, except F1, F2, M11 simple,
   others with a small projection near their bases, knife shaped, as shown
   in Figs 1-5,F1 24, F2 12, D2 43, S8 33, M11 36; with reticular
   ornamentation and about 10 pairs of discernible pore -like structures
   (lyrifissures and gland pores). Distance between gnathosomal base and
   the tip of corniculus 154(152-155), gnathosomal base width 105(94-116),
   and three pairs of smooth hypostomatal setae: anterior h1 47, outer
   posterior h2 22, inner posterior h3 33. Chelicera dentate, movable digit
   length 47, with two teeth; fixed digit with 6-7 teeth, pilus dentilis
   fme short. Palp tarsal claw 2-tined. Tritosternum base length 39, width
   18, plumose laciniae length 108. One pair of pre-sternal plates,
   surrounding area with reticular lines. Between the first pair of
   lyrifissures(iv1), anterior margin of sternal shield protruding lightly,
   sternal shield length 128 (126-130), narrowest width 98, posterior
   margin more or less straight or convex, with three pairs of smooth
   setae, St1 52(51-53), Ste2 47, St3 43, and with two pairs of
   lyrifissures(iv1-2). One pair of metapodal shields, with smooth Mst
   42(40-43), and with one pair of lyrifissures(iv3) in inner side.
   Genito-ventral shield almost tongue -shaped, length 295(290-310), width
   138(134-141), with one pair of smooth setae Vl139(38-40), posterior
   margin reaching the gap between Vl3 and Vl4, with reticular
   ornamentation before Vl1, and with Y -shape lines after Vl1. Anal shield
   subtriangular, length 108, width 105, para-anal setae length 29,
   situated behind anus median, shorter than post-anal seta(31-40), anus
   length 35(33-36). Four pairs of metapodal plates, the biggest pair
   wedge-shaped or oval, second largest pair crescent-shape. Every shield
   with reticular ornamentation. Soft cuticle with ten pairs of setae.
   Peritremes well -developed, extending anteriorly before coxa I.
   Preitrematal shield sharpening gradually behind stigmata; one fme streak
   beyond stigmata extending backward to the sharpening end; with a
   lyrifissure and a fissure behind lyrifissure. Length of every leg: I =
   666(651-680), II = 462(437-487), III= 465(458-472), IV= 687(679-694).
   Setae of legs simple and pointed, tarsus II as shown as fig. 8
   Etymology. The specific name is derived from the type locality. Remarks.
   The new species is similar to Hypoaspis(Cosmolaelaps) leptochaetes Ma et
   Lin, 2009, however the new species has a series of distinct
   morphological features which can be easily differentiated from H.
   leptochaetes. (1)The new species with 39 pairs of shorter setae on the
   dorsal shield, F1, F2, M11 not presenting knife shaped; the latter
   species with 39 pairs of longer setae on the dorsal shield, all
   presenting knife shaped except for F2. (2)The new species with
   subtriangular pre-stemal plates, surrounding area with reticular lines,
   anterior margin not with dark lace; the latter species with semicircular
   pre -sternal plates, anterior margin with dark lace. (3)Genito-ventral
   shield of the new species expanded behind level of Vl1 posterior
   extending backward to behind the level of Vl3, with reticular
   ornamentation before Vl1, with four Y -shape lines after Vl1, four pairs
   of metapodal plates, the biggest pair wedge-shaped or oval;
   Genito-ventral shield of the latter species expanded lightly behind
   level of Vl1, posterior to between Vl3 and Vl4, with simple reticular
   ornamentation, only one pair of metapodal plates, oval. Holotype
   [female], paratype 1 [female], China, Ningxia Hui Autonomous Region,
   Helan Mountain Nature Reserve of Ningxia, suyukou region(alt. 2 160 m),
   from nest of Myrmos spp., 16 June 2013, coll. BAI Xue-li, deposited in
   the Collection of the Medical Entomology of Institute of Microbiology
   and Epidemiology Academy of Military Medical Science, Beijing, China. 2
   Hypoaspis(Cosmolaelaps) liujingyuani sp. nov.(Figs. 11-19) Female.
   Idoosoma faint yellow, shape oval, length 444(437-458), width
   308(301-318). Dorsal shield completed, covering all the dorsum almost,
   length 436(430-446), width 300(293-308); with 39 pairs of setae and
   three unpaired accessory setae between D5 -.D8, except F1(length 14)
   spinous and F2(length 14) short, others with a small projection near
   their bases, knife shaped, as shown in Figs 12-15,F1 11,D2 37(36-38), S8
   25(24-26), M11 18; with reticular ornamentation and about 13 pairs of
   discernible pore -like structures(lyrifissures and gland pores).
   Distance between gnathosomal base and the tip of corniculus
   109(105-112), gnathosomal base width 85(80-90), and three pairs of
   smooth hypostomatal setae: anterior h1 29, outer posterior h2 18, inner
   posterior h3 25. Chelicera dentate, movable digit length 25(34), with
   two teeth; fixed digit with 4 teeth, pilus dentilis fine short. Palp
   tarsal claw 2 -tined. Tritosternum base length 25, width 18, plumose
   laciniae length 72. One pair of almost cap -shaped pre -sternal plates,
   posterior area with reticular lines. Sternal shield length 92(90-94),
   narrowest width 92(91-93); gracile anterior extension of sternal shield
   projecting deeply into the gap between coxa I and coxa II; middle of
   posterior margin concave upward, concave base not reaching the level of
   St3; with three pairs of smooth setae, St1 38(37-40), St2 36, St, 35,
   and with two pairs of lyrifissures(iv1-2). Genito-ventral shield almost
   tongue -shaped, length 217(210-224), width 100(96-103), with one pair of
   smooth setae Vl1 31(30-32). Anal shield Inverted pear-shaped, length
   73(67-78), width 62(59-65), para-anal setae length 19(18-21), situated
   behind anus median, shorter than post -anal seta 22, anus length
   24(24-25). The gap between anal shield and genito-ventral shield length
   24(22-25), approximate 0.88-1 times of anus length. Four pairs of
   metapodal plates, the biggest pair claviform. Every shield with
   reticular ornamentation. Soft cuticle with 15 pairs of setae, thereinto
   ten pairs on opisthosoma shaped like dorsal shield setae. Peritremes
   well -developed, extending anteriorly before coxa I. Preitrematal shield
   sharpening gradually behind stigmata; one fine streak beyond stigmata
   extending backward to the sharpening end; with a lyrifissure. Length of
   every leg: I =449(447-451), II =322, III=297(279-315), IV= 458(451-465).
   Setae of legs simple and pointed, tarsus II as shown as fig. 13.
   Etymology. The species is named to honour LIU Jing-yuan, China
   acarologist. Remarks. The new species is similar to
   Hypoaspis(Cosmolaelaps) sungaris Ma, 1996 and Hypoaspis(Cosmolaelaps)
   ningxiaensis Bai et Gu, 1993. However the new species has a series of
   distinct morphological features which can be easily differentiated from
   Hypoaspis(Cosmolaelaps) sungaris. (1) The new species with 39 pairs of
   setae on the dorsal shield, F1 spinous, most setal tips approached the
   hypogynous setal bases; the latter species with 39 pairs of setae on the
   dorsal shield, F1 needlelike, setal tips reached the middle of the gap
   between setal bases and hypogynous setal bases. (2) The posterior margin
   of sternal shield of the new species concave upward, the posterior
   margin of genito-ventral shield of the new species extending backward to
   between Vl3 and Vl4; The posterior margin of sternal shield of the
   latter species straight, the posterior margin of genito-ventral shield
   of the latter species to the level of Vl3. (3) Soft cuticle of the new
   species with 15 pairs of setae, thereinto ten pairs on opisthosoma
   shaped like dorsal shield setae; soft cuticle of the latter species with
   8 pairs of setae. The new species has a series of distinct morphological
   features which can be easily differentiated from Hypoaspis
   (Cosmolaelaps) ningxiaensis. (1)The new species with one pair of almost
   cap -shaped pre-sternal plates, gracile anterior extension of sternal
   shield projecting deeply into the gap between coxa I and coxa II, middle
   of posterior margin of sternal shield concave upward; pre -sternal
   plates of the new species absent, anterior extension of sternal shield
   projecting dumpy, middle of posterior margin of sternal shield concave
   or straight. (2) The new species tongue -shaped, with three "Y" -shaped
   lines, the biggest pair metapodal plate claviform; genito-ventral shield
   of the latter species beaker -shaped, with two "V" -shaped lines, the
   biggest pair metapodal plate sausage -shaped. (3) Soft cuticle of the
   new species with 15 pairs of setae, thereinto ten pairs on opisthosoma
   shaped like dorsal shield setae; soft cuticle of the latter species with
   8 pairs of setae, the most posterior pair stout. (4)Central prong of the
   new species cuspidal and long, Central prong of the latter species under
   lateral prongs. Holotype [female], paratypes 3 [female], China, Ningxia
   Hui Autonomous Region, Helan Mountain Nature Reserve of Ningxia, suyukou
   region(alt. 2 160 m), from nest of Myrmos spp., 16 June 2013, coll. BAI
   Xue-li, deposited in the Collection of the Medical Entomology of
   Institute of Microbiology and Epidemiology Academy of Military Medical
   Science, Beijing, China; other paratypes 2 [female] are deposited in
   Ningxia Hui Autonomous Region Center for Disease Control and Prevention,
   Yinchuan, Ningxia, China.
C1 Bai Xue-Li; Ningxia Hui Autonomous Reg Ctr Dis Control & Prev, Yinchuan,
   Ningxia, 750004, China, China.
EM nxbaixl@sina.com

SN 1005-9628

   Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; China

   liujingyuani [Ningxia Hui /  / New species].

DT Article
TI A new species of the genus Epicriopsis and a new record of the genus
   Ameroseius from China (Acari: Mesostigmata: Ameroseiidae).
AU Ma Li-Ming (mlmjls@sina.com) 
   Lin Jian-Zhen
SO Acta Arachnologica Sinica
VL 25
IS 1
PS 14-16
PD May 2016
PY 2016
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 0
AB The present paper reports a new species of the genus Epicriopsis and a
   new record of the genus Ameroseius from China. 1 Epicriopsis linzhiensis
   sp. nov.(Fig. 1) Female. Length of idiosoma 409-441 (av. 430) [mu]m,
   width 323-366(av. 339) (JAIL Dorsal shield covering entire dorsum,
   ornamented with protuberances; bearing 25 pairs of simple setae, 9 pairs
   of which very long and stout. D7 shorter than idiosoma. Sternal shield
   with concave anterior margin, St1 and St2 situated on the shield, St3
   and MSt on cuticle from the shield. Genital shield with 1 pair of setae.
   Ventro-anal shield horizontally elliptic, anus large; Ad situated at
   level of middle of anus, both Ad and PA shorter than anus. Tectum with a
   sharp anterior prong. Chela short, movable digit without tooth, fixed
   digit tridentate. Leg I 409-484 (av. 461) [mu]m long, tarsus longer than
   tibia. The new secies is near to Epicriopsis jilinensis Ma, 2002, but in
   the new species dorsal shield with 9 pairs of very long and stout setae,
   including D2 and D4; however in the latter species dorsal shield with 7
   pairs of long and stout setae, D2 and D4 short and thin. Holotype
   [female] Paratypes 6 [female], ex bark of tree, from Linzhi
   County(29[degree] 39' N, 94[degree]21' E), Xizang Autonomous Region, 24
   Aug. 2014. Type specimens are deposited in the Institute of Plant
   Protection, Fujian Academy of Agricultural Science, Fuzhou. The new
   species is named after collected locality of type specimens. 2
   Ameroseius ulmi Hirschmann, 1963 (Fig. 2) New record from China.
   Female.Length of idiosoma 462 [mu]m, width 280 [mu]m. Dorsal shield
   covering entire dorsum, strongly ornamented, with 29 pairs of setae,
   short, broader, barbed. Sternal shield with 2 pairs of setae, St3
   situated on free sclerites. MSt on cuticle from shields. Genital shield
   with 1 pair of setae. Ventro-anal shield wider than long, anus large,
   with perianal setae only. Ad situated at level of middle of anus, both
   Ad and PA shorter than anus. Ventral cuticle setae between genital and
   ventro-anal shields 4 pairs, post -ventral setae 1 pair. Metapodal
   shields 1 pair, larger, oval. Tectum arc -shaped. Chela short, fixed
   digit tridentate. Legs setae short, smooth, tarsus IV with 1 pair of
   setae slightly longer, barbed. Specimen 1[female] ex bark of tree, from
   Lasa City (29[degree] 42' N, 91[degree] 02' E), Xizang Autonomous
   Region, 21 Aug. 2014.
C1 Ma Li-Ming; Chinese Base Control & Prevent Plague & Brucellos, Baicheng
   City, Jilin Province, 137000, China, China.
EM mlmjls@sina.com
SC Zoology
SN 1005-9628
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Ameroseius; Ameroseius ulmi [China /  / New record] [Xizang /  / ]. 
   Epicriopsis linzhiensis [Xizang /  / New species]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Acari
OR Ameroseius (Acari): [New record]. 
   Ameroseius ulmi (Acari): [New record].

DT Article
TI A new species of the genus Zerconella (Acari: Mesostigmata: Zerconidae).
AU Ma Li-Ming (mlmjls@sina.com) 
   Lin Jian-Zhen
SO Acta Arachnologica Sinica
VL 25
IS 1
PS 17-19
PD May 2016
PY 2016
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the genus Zerconella is described in the present paper.
   Zerconella quasileitnerae sp. nov. (Fig. 1) Female: Length of idiosoma
   355 rim, width 194 pm. Two dorsal shields covering entire dorsum. Dorsal
   cavities 2 pairs, interior pair joining to each other. Dorsal setae
   short and simple, but s6 on anterior dorsal shield and S2-4, Z3, 4 and
   J4, 6 on posterior dorsal shield very long; J4 near to each other, J5
   lacking. Marginal setae short and simple. Lengths of setae and distances
   between setae of single rows on posterior dorsal shield in [mu]m are
   given in the Formulae of dorsal setae. Pore Po3 lies at line connecting
   setae Z4 and J3. Sternal shield with two-humped anterior margin and
   straight posterior margin, bearing 3 pairs of setae and 3 pairs of
   pores. Metasternal setae on cuticle from shields. Genital shield
   expanded posteriorly, genital setae 1 pair. Ventro-anal shield large,
   anterior margin concave, with 8 pairs of ventral setae and 3 perianal
   setae. Ad situated at level of middle of anus, slightly longer than
   anus, PA distinctly longer than anus. Peritrematal shield setae P1
   minute, P2 very long, all smooth. Peritreme short and straight, reaching
   to level of anterior margin of coxae W anteriorly. Tectum with 4 prongs
   and several lateral denticles. The new species very similar to
   Zerconella leitnerae Willman, 1953, but in the new species s3 on
   anterior dorsal shield short, however in the latter species s3 very
   long; Z3 on posterior dorsal shield of the new species longer, Z3 of the
   latter shorter. Holotype [female], ex moss, from Linzhi
   County(29[degree] 39' N, 94[degree] 21' E), Xizang Autonomous Region, 24
   Aug. 2014. Type specimen is deposited in the Institute of Plant
   Protection, Fujian Academy of Agricultural Science, Fuzhou. Name of the
   new species from "quasi -"(similar) and "leitnerae"(name of allied
   species).
C1 Ma Li-Ming; Chinese Base Control & Prevent Plague & Brucellos, Baicheng
   City, Jilin Province, 137000, China, China.
EM mlmjls@sina.com
SC Zoology
SN 1005-9628
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Asia; China
DE Zerconella quasileitnerae [Xizang /  / New species]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Acari
OR Zerconella quasileitnerae (Acari): [Sp nov, Xizang, P. 17].

TI New combinations of Mesostigmatic mites, with replacement name for
   Neogamasus palmatus Tseng, 1995 (Acari).
AU Ma Li-Ming (mlmjls@sina.com) 
SO Acta Arachnologica Sinica
VL 25
IS 1
PS 20-23
PD May 2016
PY 2016
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 0
AB The present paper reports 30 new combinations of Mesostigmatic mites,
   with replacement name for Neogamasus palmatus Tseng, 1995. Neogamasus
   tsengi nom. nov. Neogamasus palmatus Tseng, 1995 Neogamasus palmatus
   Tseng, 1995(J. Taiwan Mus., 48 (2): 23), the species name is preoccupied
   by Gu et Huang(1993) that is a hOmonymum junius of Neogamasus palmatus
   (Gu et Huang, 1993) (see this article), therefore, the former name
   should be replaced as Neogamasus tsengi, nom. nov.
C1 Ma Li-Ming; Chinese Base Control & Prevent Plague & Brucellos, Baicheng
   City, Jilin Province, 137000, China, China.

   Taxonomic position

DT Article
TI Mietticlla vespertilio, new genus new species from the Lessini Mounts
   (Verona, Veneto, Italy) Coleoptera Cholevidae Leptodirinae.
FT Miettiella vespertilio, nuovo genere nuova specie dei Monti Lessini
   veronesi (Veneto, Italia) (Coleoptera Cholevidae Leptodirinae).
AU Piva, Erminio (erminiopiva1@virgilio.it) 
SO Bollettino della Societa Entomologica Italiana
VL 148
IS 2
PS 63-70
PD May 2016
PY 2016
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 0
AB In this paper Miettiella vespertilio n. gen. n. sp. from the Lessini
   Mounts (Verona, Veneto, Italy) is described. Based on the combination of
   its characters, it belongs to the "phyletic series of Boldoria".
   Unpublished data on Monguzziella grottoloi are also given.

DT Article
TI Contribution to the study of spiders from French Polynesia. List of the
   species of the area and description of Theridion charlati n. sp and
   Glenognatha ledouxi n. sp.
FT Deuxieme contribution a la connaissance des araignees de Polynesie
   francaise. Bilan des especes presentes et description de Theridion
   charlati n. sp. et Glenognatha ledouxi n. sp.
AU Dierkens, Michael (michael.dierkens@cegetel.net) 
   Ramage, Thibault
SO Bulletin Mensuel de la Societe Linneenne de Lyon
VL 85
IS 5-6
PS 134-172
PD May 2016
PY 2016
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB This paper deals with the study of spiders caught in French Polynesia
   between 2009 and 2014. 52 species are identified. They come from Society
   Island, Tuamotu archipelago, Gambier I., Australl. and Marquesas I. Two
   new species are described from Tahiti: Theridion charlati n. sp. et
   Glenognatha ledouxi n. sp. Four other species are mentioned for the
   first time from French Polynesia: Odontodrassus aphanes Berland,
   Theridion buxtoni Berland, Micropholcus fauroti Simon and Tropizodium
   trispinosum Suman. The males of Theridion societatis Berland and
   Australaena zimmermani Berland - species formerly known only from
   females- are described. A synthesis of all known species is given for
   each island of the studied archipelagos.
C1 Dierkens, Michael; 21 Rue Garet, Lyon, F-69001, France, France.

PT J
AN ZOOR15403010331
DT Article
TI [Taxonomic and Systematic clarifications on taxa of Hemiphileurus Kolbe,
   1910, Greater Antilles (Coleoptera, Dynastidae).]
FT Mise au point taxonomique et systematique sur des Hemiphileurus Kolbe,
   1910, des Grandes Antilles (Coleoptera, Dynastidae).
AU Dupuis, Fabien (dupuisfabien@wanadoo.fr) 
SO Coleopteres
VL 22
IS 3
PS 19-29
PD May 2016
PY 2016
LA French
U1 0
U2 0
AB The study of the type of Hemiphileurus dispar (Kolbe, 1910) allows to
   clarify and to correct the taxonomy of the genus Hemiphileurus Kolbe,
   1910, in the West Indies: Hemiphileurus consimilis Ratcliffe & Cave,
   2015, is synonymised with Hemiphileurus dispar (Kolbe, 1910); the
   comparison with Hemiphileurus parvus Dupuis & Dechambre, 2000, allows to
   specify the characters of both species, to invalidate the synonymy with
   H. dispar proposed by Ratcliffe & Cave, 2015, and by application of the
   principle of the first reviser, to consider Hemiphileurus laminicornis
   Dupuis and Dechambre 2000, as a subjective synonym "junior" of H. parvus
   Dupuis and Dechambre 2000, bona species; finally a new species,
   Hemiphileurus ratcliffei n. sp. is described from the Dominican
   Republic.
C1 Dupuis, Fabien; 6 Rue Gustave Lefebvre, St Chamond, F-42400, France,
   France.
EM dupuisfabien@wanadoo.fr
SC Zoology
SN 1265-3357

   zones; Neotropical region; Central America; West Indies

PT J
AN ZOOR15312074134
DT Article
TI QUANTITATIVE DISTRIBUTION AND CALCULATION OF ECOLOGICAL AMPLITUDE OF
   LAND SNAIL Metodontia IN THE CHINESE LOESS PLATEAU AND ADJACENT REGIONS.
AU Li Fengjiang
   Wu Naiqin
   Dong Yajie
   Lu Houyuan
   Chen Xiaoyun
   Zhang Dan
   Zhang Yueting
   Huang Linpei
   Wu Bin
SO Disiji Yanjiu
VL 36
IS 3
PS 564-574
PD May 2016
PY 2016
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 1
AB Metodontia genus is among the common modern and fossil land snails in
   the Chinese Loess Plateau and adjacent regions. Metodontia huaiensis and
   Metodontia yantaiensis are the two most common species of Metodontia. Up
   to now, classification and geographical distribution of Metodontia have
   made significant progress, providing crucial knowledge for using
   Metodontia taxon as warm and moist species to decipher paleoclimatic
   changes. However, little is known about quantitative distribution and
   ecological amplitude of Metodontia, which makes it almost impossible to
   understand deeply or quantitatively paleoclimatic changes recorded by
   Metodontia. Here, land snail assemblages are collected from surface soil
   samples at 356 sites covering the Loess Plateau and adjacent regions,
   ranging in latitude from 29.75[degree]N to 43.70[degree]N and in
   longitude from 98.23[degree]E to 120.34[degree]E. Modern climatic data
   of the sampling sites are obtained by spatial interpolation on the
   40-year averaged meteorological data from a database consisting of more
   than 700 meteorological stations that is maintained by the China
   Meteorological Administration(CMA). Four climate parameters are chosen.
   Mean annual temperature(MAT)of the studied region spans from
   ca.1.2[degree]C to 16.4[degree]C, mean annual precipitation(MAP)from
   ca.210mm to 1630mm, July average temperature from ca.12.8[degree]C to
   28.0[degree]C, and July precipitation from ca.45mm to 233mm. In this
   paper, quantitative distributions of the dominant species of Metodontia
   and their relations to climate, latitude, longitude and altitude are
   reported and the optimum ranges of MAT, MAP, July average temperature
   and July precipitation for Metodontia huaiensis and Metodontia
   yantaiensis are quantitatively reconstructed using 4 weighted
   averaging(WA)models, including an inverse-deshrinking WA model, a
   classical-deshrinking WA model, an inverse-deshrinking tolerance
   downweighted WA model and a classical-deshrinking tolerance downweighted
   WA model. Results show that among all the 356 samples, 13 samples do not
   yield any snail, but 87 samples yield 2131 Metodontia individuals, which
   are identified as Metodontia huaiensis, Metodontia yantaiensis,
   Metodontia beresowskii, Metodontia cf. huaiensis, Metodontia
   wenxianensis, Metodontia sp., and Metodontia? sp.2. In the studied
   region, Metodontia with abundance more than 20% occur mainly in the
   region of MAT higher than 11[degree]C and MAP between 550mm and 850mm,
   the region to the south of 36[degree]N and to the east of 110[degree]E,
   and regions with altitude below 750m above sea level. Metodontia with
   abundance less than 10% occur on conditions of MAT between 5[degree]C
   and 15[degree]C, MAP between 380mm and 700mm, mainly in the regions of
   latitudes from 33.0[degree]N to 40.5[degree]N, longitudes from
   103.7[degree]E to 117.5[degree]E, and altitude below 2000m above sea
   level. Almost no Metodontia is observed in the regions of MAT below
   5[degree]C, MAP below 380mm, and altitude higher than 2000m above sea
   level. The calculated optimum MAT(R2=0.70, RMSEP=1.99)is 10.2
   [approximately] 14.1[degree]C for Metodontia huaiensis and 8.9
   [approximately] 14.0[degree]C for Metodontia yantaiensis; the calculated
   optimum MAP(R2=0.81, RMSEP=90.87) is 530 [approximately] 800mm for
   Metodontia huaiensis and 470 [approximately] 750mm for Metodontia
   yantaiensis. These results are useful for studies of Metodontia-based
   paleoclimate and land snail diversity.
C1 Li Fengjiang; Chinese Acad Sci, Inst Geol & Geophys, Beijing, 100029,
   China, China.
SC Paleontology; Zoology; Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Meteorology
   &Atmospheric Sciences
SN 1001-7410
BD Ecology; Abiotic factors; Physical factors; Land zones; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Metodontia [Fossil assemblages /  / ] [Environmental indicators /  / ]
   [Altitude /  / ] [Climate and weather / Paleoclimate / ] [China / Loess
   Plateau / distribution]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Gastropoda, Pulmonata, Stylommatophora, Helicoidea
OR Metodontia (Helicoidea). 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15312074134
DA 2020-09-17
ER

AN ZOOR15601007332
DT Article
TI A Review of the Haliotis of Yemen and Oman with Description of a New
   Species, Haliotis arabiensis, from Oman and United Arab Emirates.
AU Owen, Buzz (buzabman@mcn.org) 
   Regter, Wilco
   Van Laethem, Kirsten
SO Festivus
VL 48
IS 2
PS 84-92
PD May 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species, Haliotis arabiensis from Oman and United Arab Emirates is
   described and illustrated with a high resolution photo plate. Three taxa
   found along the southern and eastern Arabian Peninsula, two in Oman and
   the United Arab Emirates, Haliotis mariae W. Wood, 1828, and Haliotis
   unilateralis Lamarck, 1822, and one in Yemen, Haliotis rugosa
   multiperforata Reeve, 1846, are reviewed and compared with the new
   species. Three additional plates illustrate the other southern and
   eastern Arabian Peninsula Haliotis. A fifth plate provides a
   differential diagnosis of the four taxa.

TI A New Species of Cone Shell (Gastropoda: Conidae) from the Saharan Coast
   ofNorthwestern Africa.
AU Petuch, Edward J. (epetuch@fau.edu) 
   Berschauer, David P.
SO Festivus
VL 48
IS 2
PS 93-99
PD May 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of Lautoconus (Conidae: Puncticulinae) is described from
   the intertidal rocky environments of Dahkla Bay, central Western Sahara.
   The new species is most similar to L. guanche from the Canary Islands,
   but differs in having a stockier, more darkly-colored, and lowerspired
   shell. The new species, here named L. saharicus n. sp., is endemic to
   Dahkla Bay and the Dahkla area of Western Sahara, roughly 400 km south
   of the Canary Islands.

DT Article
TI A New Species of Harpa (Gastropoda: Harpidae) from the Coral Sea
   Archipelagos of Queensland, Australia.
AU Berschauer, David P. (shellcollection@hotmail.com) 
   Petuch, Edward J.
SO Festivus
VL 48
IS 2
PS 103-108
PD May 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of Harpa, closely related to the widespread Indo-Pacific
   Harpa major Roding, 1798, is described from the Coral Sea archipelagos
   east of the Great Barrier Reef system of Queensland, Australia. The new
   taxon, Harpa queenslandica, differs from Harpa major in being
   consistently a smaller and more lightweight shell, in having fewer
   varices per whorl, in having a much paler shell color, and in having a
   proportionally-larger protoconch that is composed of 3 Vi whorls.

   92653, USA, USA.

AB A new species of the genus Camaena Albers, 1850 is described from
   Popidolong, South East Peleng Island, East Sulawesi, Indonesia and is
   compared to four other species of this genus: Camaena gabriella f.
   subhainenensis (Pilsbry, 1890); Camaena gabriellae var. platytaenia
   Dautzenberg&Fischer, 1908; Camaena duporti (Bavay&Dautzenberg, 1900);
   and Camaena sakishimana Kuroda, 1960. It is characterized by a slightly
   flat base with a concave umbilical area and not reflected outer lip.

TI New species of Amphidromus (Syndromus) from northern Meratus Mountains,
   Kalimantan.
AU Parsons, Jeff (jeffonese@yahoo.com.au) 
SO Festivus
VL 48
IS 2
PS 113-124
PD May 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB This paper describes a new member ofthe Amphidromus (<Syndromus) adamsii
   (Reeve in Adams, 1848) group from Mount Sarempakang on the border of
   South and East Kalimantan, Indonesia. A comparison is made with other
   members of the A. (S.) adamsii group, and with extraterritorial species
   in the groups of A, (S.) contrarius (Muller, 1774) and A. (S.)
   sinistralis (Reeve, 1849). A. (S.) stevenliei new species is
   distinguishable from other members of the A. (S.) adamsii group based on
   shell and animal morphology, and conchologically separable from other
   congeners.

TI A new species Aphodius geomynidomus n. sp (Coleoptera: Scarabaeidae:
   Aphodiinae) from burrows of the pocket gopher, Geomys arenarius Merriam
   1895 (Mammalia: Rodentia: Geomyidae) in El Paso, Texas.
AU Godwin, William
SO Journal of Entomology and Zoology Studies
VL 4
IS 3 A
PS 16-18
PD May 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 1
U2 1
AB This paper reports a new species of coleopteran of family Scarabaeidae
   from far western Texas in the vicinity of El Paso, Texas. Aphodius
   geomynidomus n. sp. lives as a commensal symbiotic inquiline in the nest
   chambers of the pocket gopher, Geomys arenarius Merriam 1895 (4). It is
   distinguished from the nearest congeneric species by morphological
   features including sculpture of the head, shape of the male genitalia
   and adentate condition of the clypeus.

AN ZOOR15403018800
DT Article
TI A new species of genus Paryphostomum Dietz, 1909 (Trematoda:
   Echinostomatidae) in Phalacrocorax niger of Pakistan.
AU Abro, Muhammad Moosa
   Dharejo, Ali Murtaza
   Khan, Muhammad Munif
   Birmani, Nadir Ali
   Naz, Saima
SO Journal of Entomology and Zoology Studies
VL 4
IS 3 D
PS 246-249
PD May 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB During examination of Little Cormorant Phalacrocorax niger for the
   presence of helminth parasites, a total of 105 trematodes belonging to
   genus Paryphostomum Dietz, 1909 were recovered from intestine of 5
   hosts. These trematodes have large, elongated body, reniform head collar
   equipped with 22 spines, large acetabulum, oval cirrus sac, anterior
   testis tri-lobed, spherical ovary, broad uterus and prominent lateral
   vitellaria. These were compared with closely related species and found
   differing from their congeners in number and size of collar spines,
   acetabulum, uterus and eggs, shape of cirrus sac, position of ovary and
   position and shape of testes. On the basis of these diagnostic
   differences, a new species Paryphostomum sanghari is proposed to
   accommodate the present worm. Species name refers to the locality of
   host bird.
C1 Abro, Muhammad Moosa; Govt Coll Hyderabad, Postgrad Ctr, Hyderabad,
   Sindh, Pakistan, Pakistan.
SC Zoology; Parasitology
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Parasites diseases and
   disorders; Parasites; Helminth parasites; Hosts; Land zones; Oriental
   region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Paryphostomum sanghari [Avian hosts / Phalacrocorax niger / New parasite
   species] [Pakistan /  / New species from avian host]. 
   Phalacrocorax niger [Digenean parasites / Paryphostomum sanghari / New
   parasite species] [Pakistan /  / New platyhelminth parasite species].

   (Liosarcophaga) geetai in India.

PS 314-318
PD May 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Sarcophaga (Liosarcophaga) geetai, flesh fly is a new species of genus
   Sarcophaga reported from Aurangabad City, Maharashtra state of India.
   Sarcophaga geetai was found in the campus of Dr. Babasaheb Ambedkar
   Marathwada University, Aurangabad during the Ph.D. research work, on
   different species of forensic importance. The fly is of medical
   importance, causing myiasis and useful in determination of post mortem
   interval.

TI A new species of the genus Apanteles Foerster (Hymenoptera: Braconidae)
   from India.
AU Chougale, T.M.
SO Journal of Entomology and Zoology Studies
VL 4
IS 3 F
PS 382-384
PD May 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Apanteles indica sp. Nov. (Hymenoptera: Braconidae), a new species, has
   been described from India. The above species is parasitic on Geometrid
   Lepidopterous larva (Lepidoptera: Syntomidae). According to the key of
   Wilkinson (1928) Apanteles indica sp. Nov. runs close to Apanteles
   chilocida Viereck. by having Thorax compressed dorsoventrally, Areola
   absent. This species also runs close to the Exulonyx camma (Wilkinson)
   by propodeal carinae and tergite-III smooth. However, it differs from
   the above species by Propodeum, Tergite first, ovipositor and ovipositor
   sheath, terminal antennal segment and flagellar formula.
C1 Chougale, T.M.; Bhogawati Mahavidyalaya, Dept Zool, Kurukali, MS,
   416001, India, India.
SC Zoology; Parasitology
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Parasites diseases and disorders;
   Parasites; Insect parasites; Hosts; Insect hosts; Land zones; Oriental
   region; Eurasia; Asia; India
DE Apanteles indica [Lepidopteran hosts / Geometridae / New parasite
   species] [Maharashtra /  / New species from lepidopteran host]. 
   Geometridae [Hymenopteran parasites / Apanteles indica / New parasite
   species] [Maharashtra /  / New hymenopteran parasite species].

TI Additional note on the genus Archaeoattacus WATSON (in PACKARD), 1914:
   Description of a fourth species (Lepidoptera: Saturniidae, Saturniinae,
   Attacini).
AU Naumann, Stefan (sn@saturniidae.com) 
   Rougerie, Rodolphe
   Naessig, Wolfgang A.
SO Nachrichten des Entomologischen Vereins Apollo
VL 37
IS 1
PS 5-11
PD May 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the genus Archaeoattacus is described from Southern
   Vietnam: Arch. vietnamensis n. sp. The male holotype will be deposited
   in the collections of Museum far Naturkunde, Berlin, Germany; both
   holoytpe and female paratype ("allotype") are figured in colour. The
   nearest relative of this Southern Vietnamese endemic is shown to be the
   Himalayan Arch. edwardsii (WHITE, 1859).

TI To Research of Noctuoidea Fauna (Lepidoptera) of the Western Kazakhstan.
AU Shovkoon, Dmitry F. (shovkoon@mail.ru) 
   Trofimova, Tatiana A.
SO Entomofauna
VL 37
IS 39
PS 597-614
PD Apr 30 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Noctuoidea fauna of the Western Kazakhstan was examined by authors from
   2003 to 2012. As a result of this study the annotated list includes 200
   species. The species Rhabinopteryx turanica (ERSCHOFF, 1874),
   Heptapotamia eustratii ALPHERAKY, 1882, Eugnorisma tamerlana (HAMPSON,
   1903) and Margelana versicolor (STAUDINGER, 1888) are noted here as new
   for Europe. Guselderia lutea HACKER, KUHNA & GROSS, 1986 (nov. syn.) is
   established as a junior synonym of Heptapotamia eustratii ALPHERAKY,
   1882. 573 species of Noctuoidea known at present from the Western
   Kazakhstan are discussed.

AN ZOOR15301000610
DT Article
TI Fissidentalium (Compressidentalium) pseudohungerfordi n. sp., a well
   known undescribed scaphopod in the group of Fissidentalium
   (Compressidentalium) hungerfordi (PILSBRY & SHARP 1897) (Mollusca:
   Scaphopoda).
AU Sahlmann, Bernd (info@hausdernatur.de) 
   van der Beek, Jordy
   Wiese, Vollrath
SO Schriften zur Malakozoologie aus dem Haus der Natur-Cismar
VL 29
PS 19-32
PD Apr 30 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A huge number of shells belonging to the group which traditionally was
   called Fissidentalium (Compressidentalium) hungerfordi (PILSBRY & SHARP
   1897) was analysed. By comparison with the original diagnoses and
   pictures of the types three species were distinguished of which one was
   discovered to be unknown. Most of the specimens studied belong to this
   new species Fissidentalium (Compressidentalium) pseudohungerfordi n.sp.
   which can easily be distinguished by the lower number of ribs. Only
   shells from the South China Seas and some from Japanese waters could be
   assigned to F. hungerfordi.

DT Article
TI The herpetofauna of the Bai Tu Long National Park, northeastern Vietnam.
AU Gawor, Anna
   Cuong The Pham
   Truong Quang Nguyen
   Tao Thien Nguyen
   Schmitz, Andreas
   Ziegler, Thomas (ziegler@koelnerzoo.de) 
SO Salamandra
VL 52
IS 1
PS 23-41
PD Apr 30 2016
PY 2016
LA English
U1 0
U2 8
AB We present a comprehensive inventory checklist of the herpetofauna of
   the Bai Tu Long National Park, Quang Ninh Province, northeastern
   Vietnam. As a result of our herpetological surveys in 2008, 2009, and
   2011, a total of 29 species were recorded from the national park,
   comprising eight species of frogs, eleven species of lizards, and ten
   species of snakes. Thirteen species (or 44.8% of the total number of
   recorded species) were recorded for the first time from Bai Tu Long
   National Park, including six frog, four lizard, and three snake species.
   We provide first information on species richness and frequency of
   occurrence. The taxonomic status of three species (Hylarana sp.,
   Limnonectes cf. bannaensis, and Gekko cf. palmatus) still needs further
   clarification.
C1 Ziegler, Thomas; Cologne Zoo, Riehler Str 173, Cologne, D-50735,
   Germany, Germany.
EM ziegler@koelnerzoo.de
RI Nguyen, Truong/F-3730-2012
OI Nguyen, Truong/0000-0002-6601-0880

   richness / ] [Vietnam / Quang Ninh Province, Bai Tu Long National Park /
   New record] [ /  / ].

DT Article
TI Morphological Characteristics and Molecular Identification of Trichuris
   sp. from Giraffe.
AU Xu Qian-ming (xuqianming2006@163.com) 
   Zhao Chang-cheng
   Fang Fen
   Xu Xiao-pei
   Liu Wen-ge
   Zhang Qin
   Wang Gui-jun
SO Chinese Journal of Parasitology and Parasitic Diseases
VL 34
IS 2
PS 109-112
PD Apr 30 2016
PY 2016
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 1
AB Objective To investigate the morphological characteristics of Trichuris
   sp. from giraffe in Hefei wild zoo and identify its species using
   molecular techniques. Methods Morphological characteristics of Trichuris
   collected from giraffe were analyzed. The internal transcribed spacer 1
   (ITS-1) was amplified by PCR and the PCR product was sequenced. The
   resulting sequence was homology analysis in GenBank and its heredity
   evolution tree was constructed by MEGA 4.0 software. Results The male
   worms had a body length of 35.89-58.56 mm, an esophagus to body length
   ration of 0.29-0.40, and a spicule length of 1.96-3.89 mm. The thick and
   thin proportions of body were 7.02-23.45 mm and 28.05-40.05 mm
   respectively. These data showed different degrees of variation with
   previous reports. The PCR resulted in a product of 491 bp, comprising
   pail of 18S rRNA and full length ITS-1. Sequence alignment showed that
   the identified Trichuris was most homologous (98.6%) With T. bos taurus
   HE608848, T. capreolus JX218218, and T. Japanese AB367795, but it was
   only 46.0% homologous with T. discolor AB367794. In the heredity
   evolution tree, it was not located on the same branch as T. discolor, 7,
   Or is and T. bos taurus. Conclusions The Trichuris sp. collected from
   giraffe is different from previous reports in morphology and ITS-1
   sequence. Further research is needed to determine if it is a new
   species.
C1 Xu Qian-ming; Anhui Agr Univ, Coll Anim Sci & Technol, Hefei, 230036,
   China, China.
EM xuqianming2006@163.com
SC Zoology; Parasitology; Anatomy &Morphology; Reproductive Biology;
   Genetics &Heredity; Evolutionary Biology
SN 1000-7423
BD Techniques; Biometrics; General morphology; Reproduction; Genetics;
   Evolution; Parasites diseases and disorders; Parasites; Helminth
   parasites; Hosts
DE Giraffa camelopardalis [Nematode parasites / Trichuris / Parasite
   morphology]. 
   Trichuris [Identification techniques /  / ] [Size / Body length / ]
   [General morphology / Morphological characteristics / ] [Reproductive
   system / Spicules length / ] [Molecular genetics / 18S rRNA ITS-1
   sequences / ] [Phylogeny /  / ] [Mammalian hosts / Giraffa
   camelopardalis / ]. 
TN Chordates; Invertebrates; Mammals; Nematodes; Ungulates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Mammalia, Artiodactyla, Giraffidae,
   Nematoda
OR Giraffa camelopardalis (Giraffidae): [Host]. 
   Trichuris (Nematoda): [Parasite]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15609065934
DA 2020-09-17

AN ZOOR15609065935
PM 30124240
DT Article
TI Morphological and Molecular Identification of Acanthamoeba sp., A New
   Pathogen for Human Respiratory Tract Infection.
AU Qiao Yan
   Peng Heng
   Zhu Huai-min (hmzhu@hotmail.com) 
   Yan Ji-zhou
SO Chinese Journal of Parasitology and Parasitic Diseases
VL 34
IS 2
PS 113-117
PD Apr 30 2016
PY 2016
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 0
AB Objective To identify the species of a morphologically Acanthamoeba-like
   pathogen in sputum from a patient with repeated cough. Methods Protozoa
   were isolated from the sputum and cultured for morphological observation
   of the trophozoiles and cysts. DNA was extracted from the cultivated
   sample, and PCR was performed using primers as follows: 18S universal
   primers for amoeba family (Ami6F1 and Ami9R) and for amoeba genus (JDP1
   and JDP2), and primers for 18S full-length sequence of S-7 ATCC
   reference strain of A canthamoeba griffini (AacGF and AscGR). The 18S
   rRNA was sequenced, followed by homology analysis. The maximum
   likelihood method was used to construct phylogenetic tree. Results
   Microscopic examination showed that the trophozites had spine and
   irregular-shape pseudopodia bulge. The cysts were encapsulated by double
   membrane layer with the inner membrane having star-like processes. As
   expected, PCR amplification resulted in bands of 830, 479 and 1 957 lip,
   respectively, which were blasted to he 99%, 99% and 100% homologous to
   those of A. (107412,1). Phylogenetic tree indicated that this
   acanthamobe in the patient's sample was 91.4%, 99.6%, 94.5% and 91.8%
   homologous to keratitis-associated A. caste A. polyphage, A.
   cullbertsoni and A. rhysodes. Conclusion The parasite in sputum of the
   patient with respiratory tract, infection is A canthamoeba griffini.
C1 Zhu Huai-min; Second Mil Med Univ, Dept Med Microbiol & Parasitol,
   Shanghai, 200082, China, China.
EM hmzhu@hotmail.com
SC Cell Biology; Zoology; Genetics &Heredity; Evolutionary Biology;
   Parasitology
SN 1000-7423
BD Cytology; Genetics; Evolution; Parasites diseases and disorders; Hosts
DE Acanthamoeba [General cell ultrastructure / General morphology / new
   record] [Molecular genetics / 18S rRNA sequences / ] [Phylogeny /  / ]
   [Human hosts /  / ]. 
TN Protozoans
ST Protozoa, Sarcomastigophora, Sarcodina, Rhizopoda, Lobosea, Gymnamoebia,
   Amoebida
OR Acanthamoeba (Amoebida): [Parasite]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15609065935
DA 2020-09-17
ER

AN ZOOR15302007987

TI Revision of the north African Species of the Genera Penestoglossa
   ROGENHOFER, 1875, Dissoctenioides REBEL, 1935 and Pseudofumea REBEL,
   1935 (Lepidoptera, Psychidae).
FT Revision der nordafrikanischen Arten der Gattungen Penestoglossa
   ROGENHOFER, 1875, Dissoctenioides REBEL, 1935 und Pseudofumea REBEL,
   1935 (Lepidoptera, Psychidae).
AU Sobczyk, Thomas (ThomasSobczyk@aol.com) 
   Blaesius, Rolf
   Nuss, Matthias
SO Entomofauna
VL 37
IS 41
PS 629-684
PD Apr 30 2016
PY 2016
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Moroccan species of the genera Penestoglossa, Dissoctenioides and
   Pseudofumea are revised. The tribus Dissoctenioidini REBEL, 1936
   nov.syn. is synonymized with Luffini TUTT, 1902, and the latter are
   transferred to the subfamily Typhoniinae. Two species are transferred
   from Penestoglossa to Dissoctenioides, Dissoctenioides pyrenaella
   HERRMANN, 2006 nov.comb. and Dissoctenioides mauretanica (REBEL, 1940)
   nov.comb. The following taxa are described as new: Penestoglossa anella
   nov.sp., Penestoglossa simulata nov.sp., Penestoglossa gaetula nov.sp.,
   Penestoglossa opaca nov.sp., Dissoctenioides agamentaga nov.sp.,
   Dissoctenioides demnatensis nov.sp., and Dissoctenioides heyerae nov.sp.
   For all species, morphological characters of the males are described. As
   far as known, descriptions are also given for the females and the cases.
   The DNA barcode could be sequenced for 13 species investigated and
   analysed using neighbor-joining.
